Subject: Report and recommendation of the president to ADB's Board of Directors for the Municipal Natural Gas Infrastructure Development Project in the People's Republic of China.
Title: Report and Recommendation of the President: People's Republic of China, Municipal Natural Gas Infrastructure Development Project (Phase 2)

Municipal Natural Gas Infrastructure Development 
Project (Phase 2)

 NOTES 

The fiscal year (FY) of the guarantor ends on 31 March. FY before a calendar 
year denotes the year in which the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2009 ends on 31 
March 2009. The fiscal year of the borrower ends on 31 December and therefore 
is denoted in calendar years unless otherwise noted. 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.

 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1.
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Zhongran Investment Limited (ZIL) for the Municipal Natural Gas Infrastructure Development 
Project (Phase 2) in the People's Republic of China (PRC). If approved, the project will 
constitute the 28th private sector investment of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in the PRC. 
The report also describes a proposed technical assistance (TA) to be provided by the Multi-
Donor Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility, and if the 
Board approves the proposed loan, 1, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, 
will approve the TA. 1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix. 

II. 

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

A. 

Project Identification and Selection 

Background.  The PRC has abundant undeveloped indigenous natural gas reserves, 
2.
estimated at approximately 2.46 trillion cubic meters (tcm) in 2009, 2  which have significant 
potential to mitigate global climate change, address regional environmental concerns such as 
acid rain, and increase energy security. The Government of the PRC aims to reduce coal 
consumption and increase usage of natural gas, a cleaner fue1, 3  from its current share of 4% of 
energy consumed to 10% by 2020. 

To achieve this target, the government has restructured its largest gas producing 
3.
companies and implemented a program of large-scale international and domestic trunk pipeline 
networks, such as the Central Asia pipeline and the West—East pipelines. The development of 
downstream gas distribution infrastructure is, however, still a bottleneck to the scaling up of the 
natural gas market. A number of municipalities have faced shortages of natural gas over the last 
several years. Most affected are newly emerging small and medium-sized "satellite" cities on the 
outskirts of medium-sized and large "hub" cities which are not connected to natural gas pipeline 
networks. 4  

Shortly after an acute natural gas shortage in the winter of 2009, 5  ADB held discussions 
4.
with China Gas Holdings Limited (CGH), which had implemented the Municipal Natural Gas 
Infrastructure Development Project (Phase 1), 6  to provide through public-private partnerships 
(PPPs) approximately 200 million cubic meters (mcm) of natural gas per annum to industry and 
commercial users and 1.3 million domestic households, and to introduce compressed natural 

1 
 Contributors: the governments of Australia, Norway, Spain, and Sweden. 
2  BP plc. 2010.  BP Statistical Review of World Energy 2010.  London. 
3  One million cubic meters (mcm) of natural gas can replace 1,350 tons of coal consumption. 
4  The Urban Planning Law of PRC issued on 26th December 1989 by the National People's Congress defines a city 
with a nonagricultural population in urban and suburban districts of not less than 500,000 as a "large-sized city", a 
city with nonagricultural population in urban and suburban districts of less than 500,000 but not less than 200,000 
as a "medium-sized city", and a city with a nonagricultural population in urban and suburban districts of less than 
200,000 as a "small-sized city". 
In the winter of 2009, natural gas supplies were diverted to northern PRC to support snowstorm recovery. As a 
result, many municipalities faced their worst natural gas shortage in years. 

6  ADB. 2006.  Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Proposed Equity Investment 
and Loans to the People's Republic of China for the Municipal Natural Gas Infrastructure Development Project. 
Manila. On 30 August 2006, the Board approved (i) an equity investment of up to $25 million equivalent in Hong 
Kong dollars in CGH; (ii) an A-loan of up to $50 million equivalent, of which up to 50% was to be in US dollars and 
the balance in yuan; and (iii) a B-loan of up to $75 million to Zhongran Gas Industrial (Shenzhen) Limited and ZIL, 
fully owned PRC subsidiaries of CGH. The B-loan was subscribed among 12 banks through successful syndication. 

5 

 2 

gas (CNG) for buses and taxis in northern, central, and western PRC. ADB played a catalytic 
role not only in the total financial plan by satisfying equity and US dollar and yuan loan 
requirements and mobilizing additional funds from international banks to finance phase 1, but 
also in improving corporate governance,  7  developing a formal environmental and social 
management system, and enhancing the institutional capacity. 

5.
To date, CGH's network coverage has been limited to regional hub cities. To seize 
business opportunities through expanded market coverage, and also with the intention of 
fulfilling social responsibilities, CGH applied for further ADB assistance to extend additional 
natural gas pipelines to satellite cities to ensure stable supply. Through its due diligence 
process, ADB has determined the proposed project embodies ADB's strategies in terms of 
environmental sustainability, inclusive growth, financial and technical feasibility, potential for 
carbon reduction, and demonstration impact. 

B. 

Sector Background 

Demand and Supply.  Historically, a significant demand—supply gap in natural gas has 
6.
been observed in the PRC. Given future needs, and compounded by the PRC's increasing role 
in global efforts to combat climate change, the demand for natural gas is expected to grow 
further. Natural gas consumption in the PRC in 2007 was 69.5 billion cubic meters (bcm), of 
which the residential sector accounted for 19.2%, the commercial sector 2.5%, the industry 
sector 68.1%, and the power generation sector 10.2%. Consumption increased by 31% to 91.0 
bcm in 2009, and it is estimated to reach 105-110 bcm in 2010. Nevertheless, per capita gas 
consumption in the PRC is  still  among the lowest in gas-consuming countries in Asia and the 
rest of the world. Recent studies estimate that annual natural gas consumption will grow to 
around 210 bcm by 2020, which implies a 7%-8% compounded annual growth rate (CAGR). 
Per capita consumption in 2020 is estimated at 150 cubic meters (m 3), which is more than 
double the level in 2008 but still below current levels in Pakistan and Indonesia, and less than 
one-tenth of the average in Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) 
countries. 

Supply has been a key constraint on the growth of the PRC natural gas market. This  is 
7.
being addressed with a broad-based supply development program encouraged by the 
government. Annual natural gas supply is expected to grow to 208-275 bcm by 2020, with an 
8%-11% CAGR, to consist of domestic production (65.9%), pipeline imports from Central Asia 
(12.7%) and Myanmar (2.5%), and imported liquid natural gas (LNG, 18.9%). Domestic natural 
gas reserves are located mainly in Gansu, Inner Mongolia, Qinghai, Shaanxi, Sichuan, and 
Xinjiang, far from consumption centers. Lack of a transmission pipeline network has been a key 
constraint on connecting these supplies to ready markets. Implementation of the West—East 
Pipeline 8(WEP) has enhanced domestic natural gas production, which has almost doubled in 
the past 5 years from 51 bcm in 2005 to approximately 95 bcm in 2010. Since 2010 the PRC 
has also started importing gas by pipeline. The Central Asia pipeline, which runs 1,800 km from 

7 

During the phase 1 due diligence, ADB identified that CGH's corporate governance was one of the key areas 
where ADB could add value. ADB obtained the right to nominate a person to be appointed as a nonexecutive 
director on the CGH board throughout the period that ADB holds equity shares. In addition, ADB negotiated with 
CGH to comply with international best practices in corporate governance and also undertake the corporate 
governance improvement program as a covenant in the loan agreement. In recognition of the effort over years to 
enhance corporate transparency and responsibility, CGH received various awards in corporate governance. 

8 The West—East Pipeline is a 3,900 kilometer (km) trunk line with 12 bcm of capacity and 10 pipeline 
interconnections; a second and third phase will bring total capacity to 72 bcm by 2014. Other large projects will 
supply gas from production centers in central and southern PRC. Official plans envision the PRC's gas pipeline 
growing from 32,000 km at the end of 2008 to 60,000-70,000 km by 2015. 

 3 

Turkmenistan through Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan to the PRC, will expand capacity from 6 bcm 
in 2010 to a potential 30 bcm by 2012. There are planned pipeline imports from Myanmar (6 
bcm) and potentially eastern Russia (up to 70 bcm). 

C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 

ADB's long-term strategic framework 2008-2020 (Strategy 2020) 9  emphasizes support 
8. 
for achieving poverty reduction and inclusive growth through environmentally sustainable 
development and private sector development. The project is consistent with the strategy, which 
identified infrastructure and environment as two of the five core areas in which ADB will employ 
its financial and institutional resources to maximize results, efficiency, and impact. In terms of 
infrastructure, specifically energy, the project will embody the strategy, which sets forth that 
ADB will (i) help expand the supply of energy; (ii) promote energy efficiency through supply-side 
and demand-side measures; (iii) support clean energy; and (iv) facilitate the removal of policy, 
institutional, regulatory, technological, and legal constraints on promoting efficient energy use. 
With respect to the environment, the project is in line with the strategy's focus on climate change, 
livable cities, and complementary actions. The strategy also aims to promote a larger role for 
the private sector in financing infrastructure by supporting  PPP. 

2. 

Consistency with the Country Strategy 

ADB's country partnership strategy for the PRC is based on four development pillars: (i) 
9.
inclusive growth and balanced development, (ii) resource efficiency and environmental 
sustainability, (iii) regional cooperation and public goods, and (iv) an environment conducive to 
private sector development. 10  The project will be an integral part of ADB's PRC country strategy 
and will complement ADB's overall support for urban development in the PRC through 
investment projects and knowledge products. In particular, the project benefits from public 
sector operations in environmental protection of urban centers, 11  and municipal infrastructure 
development in small cities and towns. 12  

10.
The PRC has been steadily turning to market-oriented and private-sector-led 
development, which has become the driving force for economic growth and job creation. ADB's 
private sector operations in the PRC have focused on infrastructure, energy, finance, and 
environmental improvement, which are built upon ADB's public sector's policy advice to the 

9  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020:  The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008-2020. 

Manila. 

10  ADB. 2008.  Country Partnership Strategy: People's Republic of China, 2008-2010.  Manila. 
ii ADB. 2008.  Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Proposed Loan to the 
People's Republic of China for the Xinjiang Municipal Infrastructure and Environmental Improvement Project. 
Manila; ADB. 2010.  Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Proposed Loan to 
the People's Republic of China for the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region Environment Improvement Project 
(Phase!!).  Manila. 

12  ADB. 2009.  Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Proposed Loan and 
Administration of Grant to the People's Republic of China for the Liaoning Small Cities and Towns Development 
Demonstration Sector Project.  Manila; ADB. 2009.  Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of 
Directors on Proposed Loan and Administration of Grant to the People's Republic of China for the Shanxi Small 
Cities and Towns Development Demonstration Sector Project.  Manila; ADB. 2009.  Report and Recommendation 
of the President to the Board of Directors on Proposed Loan and Administration of Grant to the People's Republic 
of China for the Hebei Small Cities and Towns Development Demonstration Sector Project.  Manila; ADB. 2010. 
Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on Proposed Loan to the People's 
Republic of China for the Guangxi Southwestern Cities Development Project.  Manila. 

 4 

government on private sector development. Regarding infrastructure and energy, ADB 
prioritizes pioneering projects with innovative contractual and financial structuring to encourage 
private sector participation, enhance management expertise, and improve corporate 
governance. 

3. 

Consistency with the Energy Policy 

ADB's Energy Policy 13  requires energy operations to be aligned with ADB's overall 
11.
strategy of emphasizing energy security, facilitating a transition to a low-carbon economy, 
universal access to energy, and achieving ADB's vision of a region free of poverty. The policy 
requires ADB to help developing member countries provide reliable, adequate, and affordable 
energy for inclusive growth in a socially, economically, and environmentally sustainable way. It 
sets out three pillars for policy implementation: (i) promoting energy efficiency and renewable 
energy; (ii) maximizing access to energy for all; and (iii) promoting energy sector reform, 
capacity building, and governance. The proposed project is in line with the policy, as further 
penetration of natural gas will contribute to promoting energy efficiency and enhanced access to 
clean energy. 

A. 

Project Description 

Ill. 

THE PROJECT 

12.
The project is the second phase of ADB's intervention to address the financial 
constraints on developing natural gas transportation infrastructure, which is the key obstacle to 
natural gas market development in the PRC. The project will build on and expand the network 
into satellite cities on the outskirts of cities where CGH currently operates natural gas 
distribution services with the assistance of ADB under phase 1. The project will support CGH in 
building a series of pipeline networks and making gas connections to domestic household, 
commercial, and industrial end users in central and western regions 14  of the PRC. ADB's loan 
will be channeled to subproject companies through ZIL, a wholly owned subsidiary of CGH. 

1. 

The Sponsor and Borrower 

a. 

Sponsor 

CGH, the sponsor and guarantor of the ADB loan, is one of the main private natural gas 
13.
distribution companies in the country and owns one of the largest pipeline networks. Following 
the government's policy to introduce the private sector to the natural gas distribution sector in 
2002, CGH builds and operates downstream natural gas distribution, supplying residential, 
industrial, and commercial end users with gas to replace the use of coal and coal gas. Where 
appropriate, CGH builds CNG refilling stations for vehicles to replace gasoline. In FY2009, CGH 
entered the liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) distribution business to be an integrated gas 
distribution company. CGH operates in a business environment in which it has an extremely 
strong franchise and customer base due to its exclusive market position in municipalities that 
cover around 4% of market share in the PRC. CGH is underpinned by strong technological 
capabilities; a competitive edge in competitive procurement, facilities, and maintenance services; 

13  ADB. 2009.  Energy Policy.  Manila. 
14  The central and western regions include Shanxi, Inner-Mongolia, Liaoning, Jilin, Heilongjiang, Anhui, Jiangxi, 
Henan, Hubei, Hunan, Guangxi, Chongqing, Sichuan ,Guizhou , Yunnan, Tibet, Shan'xi, Gansu, Ningxia, Xinjiang 
and Qinghai, in accordance with the official definition in the Catalogue of Priority Industries for Foreign Investment 
in Central and Western China (2008) issued jointly by the Ministry of Commerce and the NDRC. 

 and solid operational capabilities. CGH is publicly listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Its 
main shareholders are presented in Table 1. 

5 

Table 1: China Gas Holdings Limited Shareholders 
(%) 

Shareholders 
Xu Xau Lan

Source: China Gas Holdings Limited Annual Report 2010 and ADB. 

Share 
18.6 
7.1 
6.8 
6.2 
6.2 
4.5 
50.6 
100.0 

14.
CGH's board comprises 13 members: five executive directors and eight nonexecutive 
directors including three independent nonexecutive directors. CGH has approximately 16,000 
employees, almost all of whom are located in the PRC. 

The borrower of ADB's loan will be ZIL, 16  a wholly owned subsidiary of CGH. ZIL was 
15.
established as a PRC investment holding company with approval from the Ministry of 
Commerce in 2006. 

b. 

Borrower 

2. 

Project Design 

16.
The project is designed to be a least-cost solution to achieving energy and 
environmental objectives. Natural gas distribution infrastructure in satellite cities tends to be 
sma11, 16  and thus involves relatively high transaction costs for financing. ADB and CGH aim to 
finance a series of small subprojects on a consolidated basis to reduce financing transaction 
costs. To ensure affordability, a TA component (paras. 36-39) aims to assist in developing 
energy efficiency solutions to enable natural gas to compete with coal. 

CGH is responsible for identifying, evaluating, selecting, negotiating, implementing, and 
17.
administering all subproject companies. For each municipality, a special-purpose subproject 
company will be set up with project equity from ZIL. The operation and maintenance (O&M) of 
each subproject will be undertaken by in-house engineers trained by CGH. The key personnel 
of the O&M team will be seconded from CGH, which has expertise in gas distribution operation. 

18.
The project puts its geographic focus on the central and western regions, where (i) the 
obstacles are more prominent due to underdevelopment of infrastructure, (ii) an untapped 
market for natural gas distribution exists, and (iii) gas supply from the West—East pipeline phase 
2 and/or Central Asia pipeline is available. Despite the benefits of proximity to natural gas fields, 
access to clean energy is limited since the municipalities tend to lack capital and operational 

i ZIL s also the borrower of the ADB phase 1 loan. 

15 
16  An average satellite city would have a total population of around 500,000, total connectable urban population of 
300,000, 3 potential industrial users, 50 potential commercial users, and 1 CNG station to service the city taxi and 
bus fleets. 

 6 

know-how. In 2008 the per capita nominal gross domestic product of the provinces of the initial 
target cities were $2,629 in Shaanxi, $2,525 in Hunan, and $2,156 in Guangxi, significantly 
below the national average of $3,315 and approximately half the levels in affluent provinces 
such as Jiangsu or Guangdong. 17  

3. 

Project Outputs and Outcome 

19. 
The project outputs will be (i) creation of subproject companies in small and medium- 
sized cities and (ii) construction of gas distribution networks and facilities. The TA outputs will be 
(i) documented integrated energy saving solutions for residential, commercial, and industrial 
users, and (ii) training provided to CGH management on combining fuel conversion and energy 
efficiency. Some of the subproject companies will undertake pilot cases to promote energy 
efficiency solutions. 

20. 
The project's outcome will be to provide residential, industrial, and commercial 
consumers with a clean, reliable, and long-term energy source in a financially and 
environmentally sustainable manner. The design and monitoring framework is presented in 
Appendix. 

B. 

Development Impact 

1. 

Contribution to Economic Growth and Poverty Reduction 

The project contributes to the PRC's efforts to promote the use of natural gas to 
21. 
enhance energy diversification and address environmental degradation. The project will provide 
residential and commercial users with clean and reliable energy for cooking and heating. It will 
also substitute natural gas for coal, oil and coal gas for industrial users, and thereby contribute 
significantly to reducing air pollution. The reduction of particulates and sulfur dioxide (SO 2) from 
industries and households will abate urban environmental degradation and have the most 
beneficial impact on the urban population, in particular the urban poor, who suffer severely from 
indoor and outdoor air pollution. 18  

2. 

Private Sector Development 

22. 
The project supports the government's strategy of encouraging private sector 
participation in the municipal natural gas distribution sector, given the substantial investment 
required in expanding the natural gas pipeline network and the limited self-financing capacity 
and operational know-how of the municipalities. The project demonstrates a robust and efficient 
model for private sector participation in natural gas supply and other municipal environmental 
infrastructure through the PPP model in small and medium-sized cities in the relatively 
underdeveloped central and western regions of the PRC, given the substantial capital required 
in implementing municipal environmental infrastructure and the limited self-financing capacity of 
the municipalities. 

3. 

Economic Sustainability 

The economic benefits of the project are significant. The expected project economic 

23. 
internal rate of return is 21%. 

17   National Bureau of Statistics. 2009.  China Statistical Yearbook 2009.  Beijing. 
18  Compared with coal on an energy-equivalent basis, natural gas combustion releases 44% less carbon dioxide, 

88% less nitrogen oxides, and almost 100% less SO2. 

 7 

C. 

Environmental and Social Dimensions 

1. 

Environmental Safeguards 

The project will contribute to improved urban air quality and health in the PRC and 
24.
reduced emissions of air pollutants, including greenhouse gases. The anticipated environmental 
impacts of construction of the subproject pipelines are low, short-term, and localized, and can 
be mitigated through sound engineering practices. The size of the citygate station is limited 
(requiring less than 0.5 hectares [ha] of land) and potential pollution is small in scale. Emissions 
are expected to be minimal from these facilities, except for occasional gas flaring. The project is 
therefore categorized B. Consistent with the PRC safeguard requirements, each subproject is 
required to prepare an environmental impact assessment or initial environmental examination in 
accordance with ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) for submission to ADB together with 
the annual monitoring report. 

For the phase 1 project, government environmental clearances were secured prior to the 
25.
start of construction of the facilities. Phase 2 subprojects will also comply with such 
requirements and submit environmental impact assessment or initial environmental examination 
reports to ADB and the government for approval. A safeguard audit report on phase 1 facilities 
prepared by a staff consultant indicated cleanness and prudent management on site. Noise 
barriers are installed where necessary to minimize impacts to the community near the gas 
compression facility. Pipeline repair works were undertaken during the nonpeak hours or in the 
night to minimize inconvenience to road users. Truck drivers have gone through strict safety 
training for CNG transport where pipelines are not connected. 

26.
A corporate-level environmental and social management system (ESMS) was adopted 
by CGH in May 2010 as an updated and integrated system developed from an environmental 
management system and resettlement framework during phase 1, and training and awareness 
building exercises have been ongoing with staff at both corporate and site levels. The ESMS 
has heavy focus on safety and emergency response (to accidental fire  or  explosion of the gas 
pipes and facilities), which is embedded in the Corporate Standard Safety Management Code, 
while an emergency response plan has become a part of the ESMS and is considered adequate. 

2. 

Social Safeguards 

The project is classified category B for involuntary resettlement, as land requirements for 
27. 
gas distribution infrastructure are likely to be limited and resettlement is usually carried out by 
the municipal government. With respect to indigenous peoples, the project is classified category 
C since the project will be implemented in mainly medium-sized cities and no impacts specific to 
ethnic minorities are expected. As mentioned in para. 26, a corporate ESMS has been adopted 
by CGH. While the overall project impact is expected to be positive, potential limited involuntary 
resettlement impacts of each subproject company will be dealt with according to the 
resettlement planning policy within the corporate ESMS. The resettlement planning policy 
details the process on procedure for screening, conduct of socioeconomic survey, delivery of 
compensation, consultation and disclosure, provision for grievance redress, monitoring and 
evaluation, and, lastly, provision for needed resources and institutional arrangements. CGH, 
together with the relevant subproject companies, will ensure that all land acquisition and 
resettlement activities are undertaken in accordance with the ESMS to ensure compliance with 
ADB requirements on social safeguards. The ESMS also includes work processes and 
procedures for the conduct of social assessment, preparation of resettlement plans, public 
consultation and disclosure, and monitoring and reporting arrangements. 

 8 

D. 

Financing Plan 

1. 

Project Cost 

CGH's investment plan indicates a total investment requirement of $400 million and 
28. 
includes civil works, equipment and materials, other local procurement, and working capital for 
municipal natural gas distribution subprojects in approximately 24 satellite cities surrounding 8 
hub cities from FY2011 to FY2013. Each subproject is estimated to cost around CNY100 million 
($15 million). For each subproject, CGH will require about 1 year to complete the natural gas 
receiving station at the city gate, which will require about 30%  of the  total capital expenditure 
amount. In the following year, CGH will construct pipeline networks covering major connectable 
areas, which will require about 70% of total capital expenditure. 

2. 

Financing Plan 

29. 
ADB will provide ZIL with a credit line up to $200 million to fund a series of new 
municipal natural gas distribution subprojects in CGH's investment plan. Proceeds from the ADB 
loan will be channeled to subproject companies through ZIL. This broad portfolio approach will 
enable ADB to provide financing support for multiple gas distribution subprojects that are too 
small for ADB or international banks to finance on a stand-alone basis. 

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Project Development 

CGH centrally controls all project development, procurement, and financing 
30. 
arrangements across its operations. To mitigate the risks associated with the unique aspects of 
different local markets, and to mobilize more equity funding, CGH intends to make its 
investments through subproject companies with local partners. In the case of brownfield 
subprojects where natural gas or coal gas distribution infrastructure already exists, the local 
partner (usually the municipal government or government-owned company) contributes the 
infrastructure and other assets in exchange for the share in the new subproject company. 

2. 

Anticorruption Policy 

31. 
CGH and ZIL were advised of ADB's Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) 
and the policy on Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism (2003). ZIL has 
fully complied with the policies under phase 1. Consistent with its commitment to good 
governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB will require ZIL to institute, maintain, and 
comply with internal procedures and controls following international best practice standards for 
the purpose of preventing corruption or money laundering activities or the financing of terrorism 
and covenant with ADB to refrain from engaging in such activities. Such obligations shall be 
contained in the loan documentation, which will further allow ADB to investigate any violation or 
potential violation of these undertakings. 

3. 

Project Performance Monitoring, Reporting, and Evaluation 

32. 
During project implementation, ADB will receive reports regularly on project financial and 
operational indicators, as well as other information to be agreed between ADB, CGH, and ZIL. 
Reporting will include, among other things, (i) the financial statements of ZIL, (ii) calculations 

 9 

and compliance certificates of the financial covenants, (iii) the business plans of CGH and ZIL, 
(iv) reports on the status of gas pipeline construction, (v) the number of end users by segment, 
(vi) the amount of natural gas sold, (vii) operation and maintenance costs and other 
administrative costs, and (viii) the maintenance plan for the next year. ADB will conduct annual 
reviews to monitor environmental and social safeguard requirements, credit assessments, and a 
review of development impacts, among other things. 

IV.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

1. 

Loan 

33.
ADB's proposed loan will have two tranches: an A-loan of up to $100 million funded by 
ADB, and a B-loan of up to $100 million funded by commercial banks, both to be made to ZIL, 
and supported by an unconditional, irrevocable guarantee from CGH. The A-loan will carry an 
interest rate, as well as commitment and front-end fees, as approved by ADB's Investment 
Committee. 

The B-loan of up to $100 million will have a maturity equal to or shorter than that of the 
34.
A-loan and be on terms and conditions agreed upon by the borrower and participating banks, 
with the concurrence of ADB. ADB may charge an arrangement fee and an annual 
administration fee as approved by its Investment Committee. The B-loan syndication will be 
undertaken on a best-efforts basis. 

35.
During the life of the loans, the subproject companies, the borrower, and CGH will be 
bound by financial and operational covenants stipulated in the loan agreement, including regular 
financial and operational monitoring  reports and requirements to meet minimum financial ratios. 

2. 

Technical Assistance 

a. 

Impact, Key Activities, and Output 

36.
In municipalities, natural gas connection offers a stable and clean fuel option that brings 
substantial benefits to both industry and residential households. However, connections tend to 
be limited to large industry users and high-end residential apartments that can afford the upfront 
capital expenditure of conversion from coal to gas. Coal is widely available at low cost, and is 
thus still a popular fuel option among a wide range of energy users. 

Natural gas can be more competitive if appropriate energy efficiency measures are 
37.
properly introduced. The primary objectives of the TA are to enhance the affordability of natural 
gas and thereby encourage replacement of coal in the cities where the project is to be 
implemented. This will be achieved through educating the end users and delivering integrated 
energy efficiency solutions. CGH as the sponsor of the project  can  be an effective agent and 
aggregator for systematically marketing and delivering energy efficiency to a large untapped 
segment of energy end users. This wholesale approach will enable ADB to provide technical 
support for a large number of energy efficiency projects which are often too small to support 
directly. 

 10 

b. 

Cost and Financing 

38. 
The TA is estimated to cost $662,000 equivalent, of which $592,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by the Multi-Donor Clean Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing 
Partnership Facility, and administered by ADB. CGH will finance the remainder, equivalent to 
$70,000, through in-kind contributions, including office accommodation and facilities, 
counterpart staff, and data and information collection. 

c. 

Implementation Arrangements 

39.
ADB, as the implementing agency for the TA, will be responsible for all technical 
implementation issues, but with the full support and cooperation of CGH. Consulting services 
required for the TA include 12 person-months of international consulting and 40 person-months 
of national consulting. A consulting firm will be selected using the quality- and cost-based 
selection method with simplified technical proposals. The recruitment of the firm will be in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). TA disbursements will be  made in accordance  with ADB's  Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010). 

B. 

Justification for ADB Assistance 

40.
ADB's assistance is justified based on the project's development impacts and 
demonstration effects. It will support the government's development plan and ADB's operational 
strategies. ADB's participation in the project will add substantial value in the following ways: 

(i)

(ii)

(iii)

(iv)

(v)

(vi)

The project will provide access to a clean, reliable, and long-term energy source 
to people in emerging satellite cities where adequate municipal natural gas 
infrastructure is lacking and demand is unmet. 
The project will demonstrate the commercial  viability  of natural gas distribution in 
small and medium-sized cities. CGH's business model—to extend its operations 
to satellite cities on the outskirts of its existing service areas, combining energy 
efficiency and fuel conversion to ensure affordability for further inclusive 
penetration—is innovative. CGH can leverage its existing pipeline networks to 
extend gas distribution and address demand for access to clean energy in 
emerging satellite cities. 
The project supports the government's strategy of encouraging private sector 
participation in the municipal natural gas distribution sector, given the substantial 
investment required in expanding pipeline networks and the limited self-financing 
capacity of the municipalities. 
The project is in line with ADB's long-term, PRC country, energy, and private 
sector operations strategies. The project will complement ADB's ongoing public 
sector operations in urban environment improvement. The project aims to 
address the financial constraints on developing natural gas transportation 
infrastructure, which is the key obstacle to natural gas market development in the 
PRC. 
The project reflects a continuation of ADB's effort to set more transparent 
corporate governance, environmental management, and together with the TA on 
energy efficiency will ensure the long-term sustainable growth of CGH and set 
standards in the industry. 
The project is demonstrational and catalytic as long-term US dollar funding for a 
series of small subprojects in the underserved central and western regions of the 

 11 

PRC where foreign investment is limited. Under PPP arrangements, increasing 
numbers of municipal governments require private sector partners to fund project 
equity in hard currency. However, the availability of long-term loans to finance 
project equity,  in  US dollars in particular, is limited. As a multiproject facility, the 
project will enable ADB to extend its reach to small and medium-sized cities that 
would be difficult to assist directly. ADB assistance will also play a catalytic role 
in mobilizing other commercial financing through the B-loan. 

C. 

Assurances 

41.
Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank, the 
government has been requested to confirm that it has no objection to the proposed assistance 
to ZIL. No funding will be disbursed until ADB receives such confirmation. ADB will enter into 
finance documents acceptable to ADB following the approval of the proposed financing by the 
Board of Directors. 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

42.
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, under the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board 
approve the loan to Zhongran Investment Limited (ZIL), consisting of (i) an A-loan of up to 
$100,000,000 to be provided from ADB's ordinary capital resources, carrying an interest rate, as 
well as commitment and front-end fees, as approved by ADB's Investment Committee; and (ii) a 
B-loan of up to $100,000,000 to be funded by commercial banks, on terms and conditions 
agreed by ZIL and the commercial banks, with the concurrence of ADB, for the Municipal 
Natural Gas Infrastructure Development Project (Phase 2) in the People's Republic of China, 
and on such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth 
in this report and as may be reported to the Board. 

19 October 2010 

C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr. 
Vice-President

NOTES 
The fiscal year (FY) of the guarantor ends on 31 March. FY before a calendar 
year denotes the year in which the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2009 ends on 31 
March 2009. The fiscal year of the borrower ends on 31 December and therefore 
is denoted in calendar years unless otherwise noted. 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.
